algorithms

Class KSelect

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.KSelect

  • public class KSelect
extends java.lang.Object
    identify the k-th smallest element in an unsorted array. Note that the arrays are sorted in place so make a copy of the array before using it as an argument if the array should not be modified. worse case runtime is less than O(N^2) avg case runtime is a little larger than O(N)
    Author:
    nichole

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      KSelect() 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      float findMedianOfMedians(float[] a, int indexLo, int indexHi) 
      int findMedianOfMediansIdx(float[] a, int[] b, int[] c, int indexLo, int indexHi)
      find the median index of a, while performing the same sort (or swap) operations on b and c too though not reading the later.
      int findMedianOfMediansIdx(float[] a, int indexLo, int indexHi)
      Complexity of run time: j = math.floor( math.log(N)/math.log(5)) Total cost = T( ∑ (N/(5*i)) * const ) + 2T(j/2) + j ( ¡=1 to j ) ===> It's a little more than O(j) but less than O(j*lg(j)).
      static int pivotPartition(float[] a, int indexLo, int indexHi, int pivotIndex)
      given a pivotIndex re-order the array so that all values less than a[pivotIndex] have final lower indexes and all values higher than a[pivotIndex] have indexes higher.
      protected float selectKth(float[] a, int indexLo, int indexHi, int kthIndex)
      select the smallest kth number in an unordered list of numbers.

      • findMedianOfMediansIdx

        public int findMedianOfMediansIdx(float[] a,
                                  int indexLo,
                                  int indexHi)
             Complexity of run time:

            j = math.floor( math.log(N)/math.log(5))

            Total cost =  T(    ∑   (N/(5*i)) * const   )  + 2T(j/2) + j
                           ( ¡=1 to j                   )

            ===> It's a little more than O(j) but less than O(j*lg(j)).
        Parameters:
        a -
        indexLo -
        indexHi -
        Returns:

      • findMedianOfMediansIdx

        public int findMedianOfMediansIdx(float[] a,
                                  int[] b,
                                  int[] c,
                                  int indexLo,
                                  int indexHi)
        find the median index of a, while performing the same sort (or swap) operations on b and c too though not reading the later. 
         
     Complexity of run time:

            j = math.floor( math.log(N)/math.log(5))

            Total cost =  T(    ∑   (N/(5*i)) * const   )  + 2T(j/2) + j
                           ( ¡=1 to j                   )

            ===> It's a little more than O(j) but less than O(j*lg(j)).
        Parameters:
        a -
        b - array to perform same swap operations on that a receives
        c - array to perform same swap operations on that a receives
        indexLo -
        indexHi -
        Returns:

      • selectKth

        protected float selectKth(float[] a,
                          int indexLo,
                          int indexHi,
                          int kthIndex)
        select the smallest kth number in an unordered list of numbers. the complexity of run time is greater than linear O(N) but less than O(N^2) and it looks like one could show less than O(N*lg2(N)). It should be better than quicksort because it's using the pivot only for values less than or equal to median ( so better than O(NlgN) at best and better than O(N^2) at worse).
        Parameters:
        a -
        indexLo -
        indexHi -
        kthIndex -
        Returns:

      • pivotPartition

        public static int pivotPartition(float[] a,
                                 int indexLo,
                                 int indexHi,
                                 int pivotIndex)
        given a pivotIndex re-order the array so that all values less than a[pivotIndex] have final lower indexes and all values higher than a[pivotIndex] have indexes higher. returns the new location of pivotIndex. complexity of runtime is between O(N) best case and O(N^2) worse case
        Parameters:
        a -
        indexLo -
        indexHi -
        pivotIndex -
        Returns:
